trans-unit.source: Gets the value at any depth in a nested object based on the path described by the keys given. Keys may be given as an array or as a dot-separated string. Returns undefined if the path cannot be reached.

trans-unit.source: I have test with:

I know this question is old, but I wanted to offer an extension by adding this to all objects. I know people tend to frown on using the Object prototype for extended object functionality, but I don't find anything easier than doing this. Plus, it's now allowed for with the Object.defineProperty method.

trans-unit.source: So I came up with my own. The great thing about it is that you don't have to interpolate strings. You can actually return a chain-able <s>object</s> function and do some magical things with it. You can even call functions and get array indexes to check for deep objects

trans-unit.source: Stop searching when undefined
Test for existence of nested JavaScript object key

The optional chaining proposal reached Stage 3 on the ECMAScript committee process, this will allow you to safely access deeply nested properties, by using the token ?., the new optional chaining operator:
trans-unit.target: ã‚ªãƒ—ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã®é€£é–ææ¡ˆã¯ã€ä¸Šã®ã‚¹ãƒ†ãƒ¼ã‚¸3ã«é”ã—ãŸã®ECMAScriptå§”å“¡ä¼šã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ã‚¹ã€ã“ã‚Œã¯ã‚ãªãŸãŒå®‰å…¨ã«ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒ³ã‚’ä½¿ç”¨ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ã€æ·±ããƒã‚¹ãƒˆã•ã‚ŒãŸãƒ—ãƒ­ãƒ‘ãƒ†ã‚£ã«ã‚¢ã‚¯ã‚»ã‚¹ã§ãã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ã«ãªã‚Šã€ ?. ã€æ–°ã—ã„ã‚ªãƒ—ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³ã®é€£é–æ¼”ç®—å­ï¼š

trans-unit.source: The ! keys.length || kicks out of the recursion so it doesn't run the function with no keys left to test. Tests:
trans-unit.target: ! keys.length || å†å¸°ã‚’é–‹å§‹ã™ã‚‹ãŸã‚ã€ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã™ã‚‹ã‚­ãƒ¼ãŒæ®‹ã£ã¦ã„ãªã„çŠ¶æ…‹ã§ã¯é–¢æ•°ã¯å®Ÿè¡Œã•ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚ãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆï¼š

trans-unit.source: The try/catch catches the cases for when any of the higher level objects such as test, test.level1, test.level1.level2 are not defined.
trans-unit.target: try/catch ã¯ã€ã‚ˆã‚Šé«˜ã„ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã®ã„ãšã‚Œã‹ãŒãƒ†ã‚¹ãƒˆã€test.level1ãªã©ã®ã‚ªãƒ–ã‚¸ã‚§ã‚¯ãƒˆå ´åˆã®ä¾‹ã‚’ã‚­ãƒ£ãƒƒãƒã—ã€test.level1.level2ãŒå®šç¾©ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚

trans-unit.source: The above code works fine for synchronous stuff. But how would you test something that is asynchronous like this ajax call? How do you test that? what if the response isn't json when it returns a 500 http error?
The above expression will produce undefined if obj, obj.level1, or obj.level1.method are null or undefined, otherwise it will call the function.

trans-unit.source: The above function allows you to get the value of nested properties, otherwise will return undefined.

trans-unit.source: The answer given by CMS works fine with the following modification for null checks as well
The function will return true if the object exists, false otherwise
The optional chaining proposal finally reached Stage 4 in the December 2019 meeting of the TC39 committee. This means this feature will be part of the ECMAScript 2020 Standard.

trans-unit.source: The proposal also allows you to handle method calls safely:
This works because the && operator returns the final operand it evaluated (and it short-circuits).
To see all the code with documentation and the tests I've tried you can check my github gist: https://gist.github.com/vsambor/3df9ad75ff3de489bbcb7b8c60beebf4#file-javascriptgetnestedvalues-js

You can either simply catch the exception, or make a function to test the existence of multiple levels, something like this:

trans-unit.source: You have to do it step by step if you don't want a TypeError because if one of the members is null or undefined, and you try to access a member, an exception will be thrown.

trans-unit.source: You probably wonder where all the promise & .then chains are... this could be blocking for all that you know... but using the same Proxy technique with promise you can actually test deeply nested complex path for it existence without ever writing a single function
